courseDescription: An introductory descriptive course which develops and illustrates the concepts of physics in terms of phenomena encountered in daily life.  Topics include mechanics, electricity and magnetism.  (offered fall, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to relate physics concepts to daily life phenomena
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply physics concepts to solve real-world problems

courseDescription: An introductory descriptive course which develops and illustrates the concepts of physics in terms of phenomena encountered in daily life.  Topics include sound, light, fluids and heat.  (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of sound, light, fluids, and heat
Ability to relate natural phenomena to physics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex concepts in simple terms
Ability to communicate physics concepts in an understandable way

courseDescription: Emphasizes mechanics, wave motion and heat and will also cover the needed elements of trigonometry and vectors.  Students receiving credit for PHYS 111N cannot receive credit for PHYS 102N either simultaneously or subsequently. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying trigonometry and vectors to solve problems

courseDescription: Emphasizes electricity, light, and introduction to modern physics. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Available for pass/fail grading only.  An introductory laboratory covering experiments from mechanics, wave motion, heat and sound.
Available for pass/fail grading only.  An introductory laboratory covering experiments from electricity, magnetism, and optics.

This seminar will provide students with a broad introduction to the cutting edge of physics research and its applications in diverse areas of contemporary physics.  Recommended for incoming students interested in physics and the natural sciences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with cutting edge physics research methods
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of physics concepts to solve real-world problems

courseTitle: Introduction to Quantum Science and Technology
courseDescription: Quantum mechanics has had an enormous impact on society since its discovery nearly a century ago and has been instrumental in developing technology such as transistors and lasers. This course will explore the potential benefits of emerging quantum technologies, how they will impact present and future society, and the technical challenges posed in implementing them. Students will develop a conceptual understanding of these technologies and their fundamental underlying principles of superposition, interference, and entanglement. Topics include quantum computing, quantum communications, and quantum sensing. These ideas will be explored quantitatively using basic algebra. It is strongly recommended that students have passed a college-level math class.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Quantum Technologies (Quantum Computing, Quantum Communications, Quantum Sensing)
Conceptual understanding of superposition, interference, and entanglement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex quantum principles and technologies
Ability to discuss the societal impacts of quantum technologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing technical challenges in implementing quantum technologies

courseDescription: Student participation in a supervised, undergraduate research experience for which credit will not apply to the degree.  Experience must be related to the student's major, minor or career area of interest.
Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors version of PHYS 231N.  This course also includes a Recitation Section for more in-depth discussion of advanced problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of PHYS 231N principles

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors version of PHYS 232N, including a recitation section for discussion of advanced problems.

A general introduction to physics in which the principles of classical and modern physics are applied to the solution of physical problems. The reasoning through which solutions are obtained is stressed. Topics include mechanics, fluids, and thermodynamics. This course is designed for majors in the physical sciences, engineering, mathematics, and computational sciences. Students receiving credit for PHYS 231N and PHYS 232N cannot simultaneously or subsequently receive credit for PHYS 101N and PHYS 102N or PHYS 111N and PHYS 112N. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying physics principles to solve problems

courseDescription: A general introduction to physics in which the principles of classical and modern physics are applied to the solution of physical problems.  The reasoning through which solutions are obtained is stressed.  This course is designed for majors in the physical sciences, engineering, mathematics, and computational sciences. Topics include electricity and magnetism, and optics.  Students receiving credit for PHYS 231N and PHYS 232N cannot simultaneously or subsequently receive credit for PHYS 101N and PHYS 102N or PHYS 111N and PHYS 112N. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of physics principles to physical problem-solving

courseDescription: This calculus-based course is the required introductory course for Physics majors.  In addition to the physics curriculum of PHYS 231N, this course has a recitation section for advanced problems and additional mathematical preparation for advanced courses in physics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Additional mathematical preparation for advanced physics courses

courseDescription: This calculus-based course is the required introductory course for Physics majors. In addition to the physics curriculum of PHYS 232N, this course has a recitation section for advanced problems and additional mathematical preparation for advanced courses in physics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of advanced physics concepts

courseDescription: This course offers students at the Freshman and Sophomore levels their first opportunity to work one-on-one with a research mentor to acquire and develop skills in research techniques, information literacy, research planning, proposal preparation and report writing. Research experiences may include but are not limited to hands-on instrument control to collect and analyze data, including graphical, statistical and error analysis of their data. Students will also be instructed on accepted methods for dissemination of data, including written, oral and poster presentation, as well as procedures for research proposal preparation and submission. Students will be required to deliver to their peers and department faculty at the end of semester an oral and written presentation of their research, as well as a poster presentation at an annual department or university event including the ODU Undergraduate Research Symposium.

A laboratory-oriented course designed to provide students with a broad introduction to instrumentation and techniques used in modern physics laboratories. Topics to be covered include: basic electronics with an introduction to diode, transistor and op-amp circuitry, and an introduction to physical computing using LabView and Arduino micro controllers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Introduction to diode, transistor and op-amp circuitry

courseTitle: Physics on the Back of an Envelope
courseDescription: Physicists should be able to estimate the order-of-magnitude of anything.  How many atoms of Julius Caesar do you eat every day?  How much waste does a nuclear power plant generate?   Will develop concepts, relations and numbers useful for estimation.  Will cover little new material, emphasizing already acquired knowledge.  Will help students apply physics to real-life questions and understand which physical effects are appropriate on which scales.  Seminar course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to apply physics concepts to real-world scenarios
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to present complex concepts in understandable terms

courseDescription: Fundamentals of Newtonian mechanics.  Topics include kinematics, dynamics, energy and momentum, central forces and planetary motion, and resonance phenomena.  (Offered Spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding central forces and planetary motion
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying Newtonian principles to solve real-world problems

courseDescription: Introduction to the wave nature of matter, with applications in materials science, atomic, and nuclear physics.  Introduction to relativity, including applications in mechanics and electrodynamics.  (Offered Fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the wave nature of matter
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of scientific principles to solve problems

courseDescription: This course will provide a strong foundation in the mathematical methods and applications necessary for undergraduate study of physics beyond the introductory level. The course contains a mandatory recitation section. (Offered Fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of mathematical methods in physics
Application of mathematical methods in physics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active participation in mandatory recitation section
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving physics problems using mathematical methods

courseDescription: May be repeated for credit.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with department and Career Development Services
Ability to present and explain academic relevance of work experience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating academic relevance of work experience

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.

This course offers students at the Sophomore and Junior levels an opportunity to work one-on-one with a research mentor on a self-designed research project of mutual interest, and typically within the research field of their mentor. The student will demonstrate their knowledge of the research skills covered in PHYS 297 by formulating their own research plan and then collecting and analyzing their data. Students will also be instructed in research publication skills as well as conference standard presentation techniques. Students will be required to attend at least two conferences, within and outside the university.
The hydrogen atom, radiative transitions, two-electron systems, many-electron atoms, interaction with external fields, theory of atomic spectra.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on interaction of atoms with external fields
Knowledge on two-electron and many-electron systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex atomic theories
Ability to discuss scientific theories in group settings

courseDescription: Experiments in classical and modern physics, designed to develop skills in the collection, analysis, and interpretation of experimental data. (Offered Spring)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in experimental setup and data collection
Interpretation and analysis of experimental data

courseTitle: Introduction to Nuclear and Particle Physics
courseDescription: An introduction to the structure of the atomic nucleus, natural and artificial radioactivity, nuclear decay processes and stability of nuclei, nuclear reactions, properties of nuclear forces, and nuclear models. Also, particle phenomenology, experimental techniques and the standard model.  Topics include the spectra of leptons, mesons, and baryons; strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of natural and artificial radioactivity
Understanding of nuclear decay processes and stability of nuclei
Understanding of properties of nuclear forces
Understanding of the spectra of leptons, mesons, and baryons
Understanding of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex nuclear and particle physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting spectra of leptons, mesons, and baryons
Analysing strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and conducting experiments in nuclear and particle physics
Managing and interpreting data from experiments

courseDescription: Introduction to solid state physics and materials science, with emphasis placed on the applications of each topic to experimental and analytical techniques.  Topics include crystallography, thermal and vibrational properties of crystals and semiconductors, metals and the band theory of solids, superconductivity and the magnetic properties of materials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of thermal properties of crystals and semiconductors
Understanding of vibrational properties of crystals and semiconductors
Knowledge of metals and the band theory of solids
Knowledge of magnetic properties of materials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing vibrational properties of crystals and semiconductors
Analyzing thermal properties of crystals and semiconductors
Problem solving in the context of solid state physics and materials science

courseDescription: Fundamentals of relativistic particle dynamics including particle acceleration; weak and strong focusing; linear beam optics and particle transfer matrices; linear and non-linear synchrotron motion; introduction to the statistical descriptions of particle beams; and radiation production by accelerated relativistic particles. Examples relevant to betatrons, cyclotrons, synchrotrons, and linear accelerators will be given.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of weak and strong focusing
Ability to understand linear beam optics and particle transfer matrices
Understanding of linear and non-linear synchrotron motion
Knowledge of statistical descriptions of particle beams
Understanding of radiation production by accelerated relativistic particles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and explain complex physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for understanding and applying examples relevant to betatrons, cyclotrons, synchrotrons, and linear accelerators
Problem-solving skills to understand particle dynamics

courseDescription: Introduction to computationally based problem solving in physics with an emphasis on understanding and applying various numerical algorithms to different types of physics problems. Topics will include numerical integration (quadrature), numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, Runge-Kutta and Numerov methods, polynomial approximations, numerical linear algebra, and Monte-Carlo methods. These computational methods will be applied to problems in classical and quantum mechanics, as well as electromagnetic theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations
Applying computational methods to problems in classical and quantum mechanics
Applying computational methods to problems in electromagnetic theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Computationally based problem solving in physics
Analyzing different types of physics problems
Designing and implementing algorithms for physics problems

courseDescription: A study of the classical theory and phenomena of electricity and magnetism. Topics include the calculation of electric and magnetic fields, magnetic and dielectric properties of matter, and an introduction to Maxwell's equations. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calculation of electric and magnetic fields
Understanding magnetic and dielectric properties of matter
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of electrical and magnetic phenomena
Problem solving in electric and magnetic field calculations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Active participation in mandatory recitation sections

courseDescription: A mathematical study of the concepts of mechanics. Vector calculus methods are used.  Topics include mechanics of a system of particles, Lagrangian mechanics, Hamilton's canonical equations, and motion of a rigid body.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying the concepts of mechanics
Understanding and applying Hamilton's canonical equations
Understanding the motion of a rigid body
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for solving mathematical problems

courseDescription: Introduction to the physical and mathematical structure of quantum theory, including the historical and experimental origins of the subject. The subject matter includes techniques for solving the Schrodinger equation in one, two, and three dimensions.   Both coordinate and momentum space representations are used. The harmonic oscillator and the Hydrogen atom receive particular attention.  The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Solving the Schrodinger equation in one, two, and three dimensions
Use of coordinate and momentum space representations
Knowledge of the harmonic oscillator and the Hydrogen atom
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex quantum mechanics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for solving complex mathematical problems

courseDescription: A course in electrodynamics developed from Maxwell's Equations.  Topics include Maxwell's Equations, Conservation Laws, Electromagnetic Waves, Potentials and Fields, Radiation, and the interplay of electrodynamics and special relativity. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of Maxwell's Equations
Interplay of electrodynamics and special relativity
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and explain electromagnetic concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of Conservation Laws in electrodynamics
Ability to solve problems involving Maxwell's Equations and related topics
Analyzing and understanding complex electromagnetic systems

courseDescription: A study of the fundamental concepts of thermodynamics, kinetic theory, and statistical mechanics.  Topics include the thermodynamics of simple systems, kinetic theory of gases, statistical mechanics of gases and an introduction to quantum statistics.

This course follows directly from PHYS 452.  It includes a more detailed study of simple systems, an introduction to abstract quantum mechanics and Dirac notation, and applications to operator methods.  Particular attention is paid to electron spin, angular momentum theory, operator treatment of the harmonic oscillator, the Pauli exclusion principle, perturbation theory, and scattering.  The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operator treatment of the harmonic oscillator
Understanding of the Pauli exclusion principle
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex quantum mechanics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use quantum mechanics to solve complex problems

courseTitle: Fundamentals of Accelerator Physics and Technology with Simulations and Measurements Lab
courseDescription: Explores the historical development of accelerators and their past and present applications.  Principles of acceleration, including the physics of linear accelerators, synchrotrons, and storage rings.  Magnet design; machine lattice design and particle beam optics.  Longitudinal and transverse beam dynamics, including synchrotron and betatron particle motion.  Special topics will be reviewed, including synchrotron radiation, injection techniques, and collective effects and beam instabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of longitudinal and transverse beam dynamics
Proficiency in dealing with collective effects and beam instabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex physics principles
Collaboration in lab testing and simulations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying physics principles to solve problems in acceleration

courseDescription: This course will review the style and scope of problems likely to be found on the Physics Graduate Record Exam (GRE). Emphasis is on quick solving of problems based on foundational knowledge and intuition. This course is particularly intended for students preparing to apply for graduate school, but may be of interest to all students.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying foundational Physics knowledge
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different types of Physics problems
Rapid decision making under time pressure

courseTitle: Research Methods in Mathematics and Sciences
courseDescription: Emphasizes the tools and techniques used to solve scientific problems.  Topics include use and design of experiments, use of statistics to interpret experimental results, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena, and oral and written presentation of scientific results.  Students will perform four independent inquiries, combining skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems.  Required for Physics teaching licensure track; not available as upper-division elective in content area.  This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Use of statistics to interpret experimental results
Analytical thinking in combining skills from mathematics and science
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization and execution of independent research inquiries
Leadership in problem-solving using interdisciplinary skills

courseDescription: Part one of a two-semester option for completing the Senior Thesis. This is a writing intensive course. PHYS 489W plus PHYS 490W is equivalent to PHYS 499W.
Part two of a two-semester option for completing the Senior Thesis.  PHYS 489W plus PHYS 490W is equivalent to PHYS 499W.  This is a writing intensive course.
In-depth study of a selected topic in physics at the advanced undergraduate level. May include a laboratory or computational component.
These courses afford the student an opportunity to pursue individual study and research.

Each student will undertake a research experience under the supervision of a department faculty member.  The experience can be of an experimental, theoretical, or calculational type.  A final oral and written report are required.  The research may be completed on campus or at one of the department affiliated research organizations. This is a writing intensive course.(offered fall, spring, summer)
Experiments in classical and modern physics, designed to develop skills in the collection, analysis, and interpretation of experimental data.

An introduction to the structure of the atomic nucleus, natural and artificial radioactivity, nuclear decay processes and stability of nuclei, nuclear reactions, properties of nuclear forces, and nuclear models. Also, particle phenomenology, experimental techniques and the standard model.  Topics include the spectra of leptons, mesons, and baryons; strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions.

Understanding of nuclear decay processes and stability of nuclei
Knowledge of spectra of leptons, mesons, and baryons
Understanding of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex nuclear physics concepts
Capability to collaborate in experimental setups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions

courseDescription: Introduction to solid state physics and materials science, with emphasis placed on the applications of each topic to experimental and analytical techniques.  Topics include crystallography, thermal and vibrational properties of crystals and semiconductors, metals and the band theory of solids, superconductivity and the magnetic properties of materials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge about thermal and vibrational properties of crystals
Knowledge about metals and the band theory of solids
Knowledge about the magnetic properties of materials
Application of experimental and analytical techniques in solid state physics and materials science
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the properties of different materials
Application of analytical techniques in materials science

courseDescription: Fundamentals of relativistic particle dynamics including particle acceleration; weak and strong focusing; linear beam optics and particle transfer matrices; linear and non-linear synchrotron motion; introduction to the statistical descriptions of particle beams; and radiation production by accelerated relativistic particles. Examples relevant to betatrons, cyclotrons, synchrotrons, and linear accelerators will be given.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of weak and strong focusing
Knowledge of linear beam optics and particle transfer matrices
Understanding of linear and non-linear synchrotron motion
Ability to use statistical descriptions of particle beams

Ability to work collaboratively in a laboratory or research setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying particle transfer matrices
Applying statistical descriptions to particle beams
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams in laboratory or research settings

courseDescription: Introduction to computationally based problem solving in physics with an emphasis on understanding and applying various numerical algorithms to different types of physics problems. Topics will include numerical integration (quadrature), numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, Runge-Kutta and Numerov methods, polynomial approximations, numerical linear algebra, and Monte-Carlo methods. These computational methods will be applied to problems in classical and quantum mechanics, as well as electromagnetic theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations

courseDescription: A study of the classical theory and phenomena of electricity and magnetism.  Topics include the calculation of electric and magnetic fields, magnetic and dielectric properties of matter, and an introduction to Maxwell's equations. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calculation of electric and magnetic fields

courseDescription: A mathematical study of the concepts of mechanics. Vector calculus methods are used.  Topics include mechanics of a system of particles, Lagrangian mechanics, Hamilton’s canonical equations, and motion of a rigid body.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of mechanics of a system of particles
Understanding motion of a rigid body

courseDescription: Introduction to the physical and mathematical structure of quantum theory, including the historical and experimental origins of the subject.  The curriculum includes techniques for solving the Schrodinger wave equation, particularly for the harmonic oscillator and the hydrogen atom. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying mathematical structures to physical problems

courseDescription: A course in electrodynamics developed from Maxwell’s Equations.  Topics include Maxwell’s Equations, Conservation Laws, Electromagnetic Waves, Potentials and Fields, Radiation, and the interplay of electrodynamics and special relativity. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.

Knowledge of Conservation Laws in electromagnetism
Understanding of Potentials and Fields in electrodynamics
Knowledge of Radiation principles in electrodynamics
Understanding of the interplay between electrodynamics and special relativity

Participation in academic discussions during recitation section
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying Maxwell's Equations to solve problems
Critical thinking in the application of Conservation Laws
Analyzing the effects of Potentials and Fields

courseDescription: A study of the fundamental concepts of thermodynamics, kinetic theory, and statistical mechanics.  Topics include the thermodynamics of simple systems, kinetic theory of gases, statistical mechanics of gases and an introduction to quantum statistics.

This course follows directly from PHYS 552.  It includes a more detailed study of simple systems, an introduction to abstract quantum mechanics and Dirac notation, and applications to operator methods.  Particular attention is paid to electron spin, angular momentum theory, operator treatment of the harmonic oscillator, the Pauli exclusion principle, perturbation theory, and scattering. The course contains a mandatory recitation section.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operator treatment of the harmonic oscillator

courseDescription: In-depth study of a selected topic in physics at the graduate level. May include a laboratory or computational component.
These courses afford the student an opportunity to pursue individual study and research.
Basic mathematical methods with applications: vector analysis, linear algebra, series and series of functions, Hilbert spaces, complex variable theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying series and series of functions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying complex variable theory in problem solving
Using series and series of functions to find solutions

courseDescription: Continuation of PHYS 601. Basic mathematical methods with applications: integral transforms, ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of mathematical methods to solve physics problems

courseDescription: Particle in a central-force field.  Dynamics in a rotating reference frame.  Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations.  Small oscillations.  Kinematics and dynamics of a rigid body.  Canonical transformation, Hamilton-Jacobi theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations
Knowledge of kinematics and dynamics of a rigid body
Understanding of canonical transformation and Hamilton-Jacobi theory
Skill in analyzing particle in a central-force field
Experience with dynamics in a rotating reference frame
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to solve problems involving small oscillations
Analytical skills for understanding dynamics in different reference frames
Ability to apply Hamiltonian and Lagrangian formulations to solve mechanical problems

courseDescription: Electrostatics:  Gauss' Law and Poisson and Laplace equations.  Methods for the solution of boundary-value problems with rectangular, cylindrical, and spherical symmetry.  Expansion in multipoles.  Dielectrics.  Magnetostatics and Faraday's law.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to perform expansions in multipoles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving complex electrostatic problems
Analyzing and solving complex magnetostatic problems
Applying various methods for the solution of boundary-value problems

courseDescription: Mathematical foundations of Hilbert spaces.  Background on Hamiltonian mechanics and electro-magnetism.  Postulates of Quantum Mechanics, measurements and Schroedinger equation.  Simple systems.  Schroedinger Equation in 1-3 dimensions and solutions for specific systems.  Symmetries and angular momentum.  Time-independent perturbation theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of symmetries and angular momentum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to derive solutions for specific systems
Analytical skills to understand and interpret quantum mechanics concepts
Problem-solving skills to tackle complex equations

courseTitle: Selected Topics in Pure and Applied Physics
courseDescription: These courses afford the student an opportunity to pursue individual study.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing relevant physics software and tools
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in topic selection and study

courseDescription: Special topics related to particle accelerators and their applications. Departmental approval required.
M.S. level research supervised by the student's thesis advisor.
M.S. level research supervised by the student's thesis advisor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized tools or software relevant to the research area
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building relationships with advisors and peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution development based on research findings

courseDescription: Electrodynamics:  Maxwell equations, plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation, waveguides, radiating systems, special theory of relativity, including the dynamics of relativistic particles and electromagnetic fields.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation
Comprehension of special theory of relativity
Understanding the dynamics of relativistic particles and electromagnetic fields
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex electromagnetic concepts
Ability to discuss and collaborate on advanced physics problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for solving electrodynamics problems
Ability to apply Maxwell's equations to solve practical problems

courseDescription: Review of thermodynamics.   Classical statistical mechanics and applications.  The virial expansion.  Quantum statistical mechanics and the micro-canonical, canonical, and grand-canonical ensembles.  The Fermi and Bose gases, and applications.  Special topics in statistical mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of micro-canonical, canonical, and grand-canonical ensembles
Understanding of Fermi and Bose gases
Knowledge on special topics in statistical mechanics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply statistical mechanics principles to practical problems
Analysis of various physics phenomena using statistical mechanics

courseDescription: Studies of high level computer languages.  Computational techniques used in physics.  Numerical techniques for differential and integral problems.  Algebraic processing languages.  Introduction to scientific visualization techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of computational techniques in physics
Numerical techniques for differential and integral problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying numerical techniques to solve complex physics problems

courseDescription: Further development of quantum mechanics.  Multi-particle states, bosons and fermions.  Classical Limit.  Variational principle, time-dependent perturbation theory and scattering.  Path integral formulation.  Symmetry and groups, addition of angular moments.  Examples from solid state, atomic, nuclear, and particle physics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of multi-particle states, bosons and fermions
Knowledge in solid state, atomic, nuclear, and particle physics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex quantum mechanics concepts

courseDescription: Nuclear forces, models of nuclear structure and reactions, hadron and lepton scattering, introduction to constituent quark model and hadron spectroscopy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of models of nuclear structure and reactions
Understanding of hadron and lepton scattering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze nuclear structures and reactions
Analytical skills for interpreting hadron and lepton scattering

courseDescription: Discrete and continuous symmetries and application to particle physics, SU(2) and SU(3) symmetries and static properties of hadrons.   Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations, quantum electrodynamics and Feynman rules, strong and weak interactions, Standard Model and physics beyond the Standard Model.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of SU(2) and SU(3) symmetries
Application of Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations
Knowledge of quantum electrodynamics and Feynman rules
Understanding of strong and weak interactions
Knowledge of the Standard Model and physics beyond the Standard Model
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of discrete and continuous symmetries to particle physics
Analysis of static properties of hadrons
Understanding and application of quantum electrodynamics

courseDescription: Irreducible tensor methods.  Radiative excitation and ionization processes. Atom-atom scattering.  Time-evolution of atomic observables in external fields.  Multiple channel quantum defect theory and complex atomic and molecular spectra.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of radiative excitation and ionization processes
Ability to examine time-evolution of atomic observables in external fields
Knowledge of multiple channel quantum defect theory
Ability to interpret complex atomic and molecular spectra
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze atomic and molecular spectra
Understanding and application of atomic observables in external fields

courseDescription: Overview of the underlying physics of modern particle accelerators. Beam acceleration, coupled and uncoupled beam transport, nonlinear dynamics, collective effects, phase space cooling, and free-electron lasers will be covered. Depending on the instructor, additional topics of current interest such as coherent synchrotron radiation, wakefields and impedances, and novel methods of acceleration will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of coupled and uncoupled beam transport
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze complex physical phenomena
Ability to understand and solve problems related to particle accelerators
Understanding and interpretation of complex physical systems

courseTitle: Experimental and Computational Techniques in Accelerator Physics
courseDescription: Overview of the tools and techniques used in the design of particle accelerators and the measurement of their components.  The course is targeted for both physicists and engineers, and its intent is to provide them with a common language and understanding.  The course consists of 6 modules of 2 weeks each.  Each module will be a combination of assigned readings, lectures, computer-based design, and hand-on measurements. Typical topics to be addressed in the 6 modules are: beamline design, electromagnetic cavity design, magnets, beam instrumentation, engineering principles for superconducting rf accelerators, machine learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of magnets in particle accelerators
Understanding and application of engineering principles for superconducting rf accelerators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Design and measurement of particle accelerator components
Problem-solving in design and measurement of particle accelerators
Application of machine learning in accelerator physics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization and execution of hands-on measurements

courseTitle: Classical Mechanics and Electromagnetism in Accelerator Physics
courseDescription: Further developments in classical mechanics and electromagnetism and their application to accelerator physics: Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulation of equations of motion, canonical transformations, adiabatic invariants, linear and nonlinear resonances. Louisville's theorem, solutions of Maxwell's equation in cavities and waveguides, wakefields, radiation and retarded potentials, and synchrotron radiation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulation of equations of motion
Understanding of linear and nonlinear resonances
Understanding of solutions of Maxwell's equation in cavities and waveguides
Understanding of radiation and retarded potentials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying solutions of Maxwell's equation in cavities and waveguides

courseDescription: Properties and behavior of materials and systems at low temperature with emphasis on particle accelerator and microwave applications.  Macroscopic quantum phenomena in condensates.  Superfluidity, electrodynamic properties of superconductors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of properties and behavior of materials and systems at low temperature
Knowledge on macroscopic quantum phenomena in condensates
Knowledge on electrodynamic properties of superconductors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing behavior of materials and systems at low temperature

courseTitle: Design and Operating Principles of Particle Accelerators
courseDescription: This course will introduce design and general operating principles for particle accelerators, including acceleration methods for particles and beams. Topics will include the evolution and descriptions of particle beams under acceleration, physics of accelerated particle beams, as well as the effects of space charge, high-order modes (HOMs), and other collective effects. Aspects of both normal conducting (RF) and superconducting (SRF) particle beam acceleration will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on the physics of accelerated particle beams
Familiarity with effects of space charge and high-order modes
Understanding of normal conducting (RF) and superconducting (SRF) particle beam acceleration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the evolution and descriptions of particle beams under acceleration
Understanding and mitigating the implications of collective effects

courseTitle: Introduction to the Processes of Quantum Chromodynamics
courseDescription: An introduction to basic Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) methods in hadron-scattering experiments.  Focus will be placed on perturbative methods and partonic interpretations of specific processes. The course will begin with a general overview of QCD, and specific processes will be studied in detail to illustrate the general features of patronic physics and their QCD interpretations. The course will close with a summary of questions of current research interest.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of perturbative methods in QCD
Knowledge of current research in QCD
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theoretical physics principles in problem-solving

courseDescription: This seminar is designed to enhance both written and oral communication skills as applied to physics. Topics include effective display of data, preparation of scientific reports and preparation and delivery of scientific talks.
Thorough coverage of areas selected to meet special needs and interests.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying advanced physics concepts
Data analysis with physics software tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex physics theories to peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for complex physics problems

courseDescription: Special topics related to particle accelerators and their applications.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination of accelerator operation and maintenance

courseDescription: Electrodynamics:  Maxwell equations, plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation, waveguides, radiating systems, special theory of relativity, including the dynamics of relativistic particles and electromagnetic fields.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation
Comprehension of special theory of relativity
Understanding the dynamics of relativistic particles and electromagnetic fields
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving complex problems related to waveguides
Analyzing relativistic particles and electromagnetic fields

courseDescription: Review of thermodynamics.   Classical statistical mechanics and applications.  The virial expansion.  Quantum statistical mechanics and the micro-canonical, canonical, and grand-canonical ensembles.  The Fermi and Bose gases, and applications.  Special topics in statistical mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of classical statistical mechanics and its applications
Proficiency in quantum statistical mechanics and the micro-canonical, canonical, and grand-canonical ensembles
Familiarity with the Fermi and Bose gases, and applications
Insight into special topics in statistical mechanics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply knowledge of statistical mechanics in problem solving
Analytical skills to understand complex concepts within statistical mechanics
Skill to use quantum statistical mechanics for problem-solving

courseDescription: Studies of high level computer languages.  Computational techniques used in physics.  Numerical techniques for differential and integral problems.  Algebraic processing languages.  Introduction to scientific visualization techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Numerical techniques for differential and integral problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking with algebraic processing languages
Problem solving using scientific visualization techniques

courseDescription: Further development of quantum mechanics.  Multi-particle states, bosons and fermions.  Classical Limit.  Variational principle, time-dependent perturbation theory and scattering.  Path integral formulation.  Symmetry and groups, addition of angular moments.  Examples from solid state, atomic, nuclear and particle physics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of solid state, atomic, nuclear and particle physics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying variational principle to solve problems
Analyzing scattering using time-dependent perturbation theory
Using path integral formulation for problem solving
Applying symmetry and groups to solve physics problems
Utilizing angular moments for problem solving

courseDescription: Nuclear forces, models of nuclear structure and reactions, hadron and lepton scattering, introduction to constituent quark model and hadron spectroscopy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of models of nuclear structure and reactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in nuclear and particle physics
Analytical thinking in quark model and hadron spectroscopy

courseDescription: Discrete and continuous symmetries and application to particle physics, SU(2) and SU(3) symmetries and static properties of hadrons.  Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations, quantum electrodynamics and Feynman rules, strong and weak interactions. Standard Model and physics beyond the Standard Model.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of discrete and continuous symmetries
Application of symmetries to particle physics
Knowledge of SU(2) and SU(3) symmetries
Understanding of Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations
Knowledge of quantum electrodynamics and Feynman rules
Understanding of strong and weak interactions
Exploring physics beyond the Standard Model
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex physics concepts to peers
Collaborative problem-solving in the field of advanced physics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting complex physics equations
Critical evaluation of theories and models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading study groups for complex physics topics
Organizing and synthesizing large amounts of theoretical information

courseDescription: Electronic and lattice properties of solids, band structures of metals, semiconductors and insulators, dynamics of electron and phonons, electromagnetic and optical properties of metals and doped semiconductors, phenomenology of superconductivity and magnetism, and selected experimental methods of solid state physics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of electronic and lattice properties of solids
Knowledge of band structures of metals, semiconductors and insulators
Understanding of dynamics of electron and phonons
Knowledge on electromagnetic and optical properties of metals and doped semiconductors
Understanding of phenomenology of superconductivity and magnetism
Capable of using selected experimental methods of solid state physics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for interpreting experimental results

courseDescription: Many body and collective effects in condensed matter, including phase transitions, Bose and Fermi quantum liquids, superfluidity, superconductivity and magnetism, and properties of mesoscopic and low-dimensional systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Bose and Fermi quantum liquids
Understanding of properties of mesoscopic and low-dimensional systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex physics concepts
Collaborating with fellow physicists on research projects

courseDescription: Irreducible tensor methods.  Radiative excitation and ionization processes. Atom-atom scattering.  Time-evolution of atomic observables in external fields.  Multiple channel quantum defect theory and complex atomic and molecular spectra.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of radiative excitation and ionization processes
Experience with time-evolution of atomic observables in external fields
Familiarity with multiple channel quantum defect theory
Interpretation of complex atomic and molecular spectra
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of atomic observables in external fields
Analytical interpretation of complex atomic and molecular spectra

courseDescription: Introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics; symmetries in relativistic wave equations; solutions to relativistic wave equations for bound states and scattering processes; classical field theory and role of symmetries in construction of conserved currents; introduction to second quantization of fields.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of symmetries in relativistic wave equations
Ability to find solutions to relativistic wave equations for bound states and scattering processes
Understanding the role of symmetries in construction of conserved currents
Introduction to second quantization of fields
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of quantum mechanical theories
Application of classical field theory to solve problems

courseDescription: Overview of the underlying physics of modern particle accelerators. Beam acceleration, coupled and uncoupled beam transport, nonlinear dynamics, collective effects, phase space cooling, and free-electron lasers will be covered. Depending on the instructor, additional topics of current interest such as coherent synchrotron radiation, wakefields and impedances, and novel methods of acceleration will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of coupled and uncoupled beam transport
Knowledge of novel methods of acceleration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of physical phenomena in particle accelerators
Problem-solving in beam transport and acceleration
Analyzing collective effects in particle accelerators

courseTitle: Experimental and Computational Techniques in Accelerator Physics
courseDescription: Overview of the tools and techniques used in the design of particle accelerators and the measurement of their components.  The course is targeted for both physicists and engineers, and its intent is to provide them with a common language and understanding.  The course consists of 6 modules of 2 weeks each.  Each module will be a combination of assigned readings, lectures, computer-based design, and hand-on measurements. Typical topics to be addressed in the 6 modules are: beamline design, electromagnetic cavity design, magnets, beam instrumentation, engineering principles for superconducting rf accelerators, machine learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding engineering principles for superconducting rf accelerators
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and interpretation of assigned readings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing measurements of particle accelerator components
Applying machine learning to the field of accelerator physics

courseDescription: Motion of charged particles in electromagnetic fields. Coulomb collisions and transport processes. Collisional Boltzmann equation. Generation of various forms of plasma in the laboratory. Basic plasma diagnostic methods including plasma and laser spectroscopy, measurements of electron and ion density and energy distribution.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Coulomb collisions and transport processes
Understanding of the Collisional Boltzmann equation
Generation of plasma in a laboratory setting
Measurement of electron and ion density
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of ion and electron density and energy distribution

courseTitle: Classical Mechanics and Electromagnetism in Accelerator Physics
courseDescription: Further development in classical mechanics and electromagnetism and their application to accelerator physics:  Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulation of equations of motion, canonical transformations, adiabatic invariants, linear and nonlinear resonances.  Louisville's theorem, solutions of Maxwell's equation in cavities and waveguides, wakefields, radiation and retarded potentials, and synchrotron radiation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Linear and Nonlinear Resonances
Solving Maxwell's Equations in Cavities and Waveguides
Understanding of Radiation and Retarded Potentials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for equations of motion

courseDescription: Properties and behavior of materials and systems at low temperature with emphasis on particle accelerator and microwave applications.  Macroscopic quantum phenomena in condensates. Superfluidity, electrodynamic properties of superconductors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of macroscopic quantum phenomena in condensates
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of properties and behavior of materials and systems at low temperature
Solution development for particle accelerator and microwave applications

courseDescription: The Yukawa potential in classical and quantum mechanics.  One- and two-meson exchange amplitudes.  Pion-exchange interactions: one- and two-pion exchange two-nucleon     potentials, and two-pion exchange three-nucleon potentials. Electromagnetic interactions. Nucleon-nucleon scattering. Realistic models of two- and three-nucleon potentials. Relativistic corrections to the nuclear Hamiltonian. Electro-weak currents of nucleons and nuclei.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Yukawa potential in classical and quantum mechanics
Knowledge of one- and two-meson exchange amplitudes
Application of realistic models of two- and three-nucleon potentials
Understanding relativistic corrections to the nuclear Hamiltonian
Knowledge of electro-weak currents of nucleons and nuclei
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex physics concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use models for problem-solving

courseTitle: Design and Operating Principles of Particle Accelerators
courseDescription: This course will introduce design and general operating principles for particle accelerators, including acceleration methods for particles and beams. Topics will include the evolution and descriptions of particle beams under acceleration, physics of accelerated particle beams, as well as the effects of space charge, high-order modes (HOMs), and other collective effects. Aspects of both normal conducting (RF) and superconducting (SRF) particle beam acceleration will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of acceleration methods for particles and beams
Understanding of the effects of space charge, high-order modes, and other collective effects
Knowledge of normal conducting (RF) and superconducting (SRF) particle beam acceleration
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex physics concepts
Ability to present findings on accelerated particle beams
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills to understand the physics of accelerated particle beams
Ability to evaluate and mitigate the effects of space charge and high-order modes

courseTitle: Introduction to Quantum Field Theory I
courseDescription: Quantization of the Klein-Gordon field, interactions in quantum field theory and Feynman diagrams, quantization of the Dirac field, quantization of the electromagnetic field, quantum electrodynamics, renormalization, quantum chromodynamics and asymptotic freedom.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex quantum field theory concepts
Collaborating on theoretical or mathematical problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical knowledge to practical quantum field problems

courseTitle: Introduction to Quantum Field Theory II
courseDescription: Further development of topics in quantum field theory. The course addresses renormalization, non-abelian gauge theories, and advanced calculation techniques.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex quantum field theory concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for solving quantum field theory problems
Critical thinking in developing advanced calculation techniques

courseTitle: Introduction to the Processes of Quantum Chromodynamics
courseDescription: An introduction to basic Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) methods in hadron-scattering experiments. Focus will be placed on perturbative methods and partonic interpretations of specific processes. The course will begin with a general overview of QCD, and specific processes will be studied in detail to illustrate the general features of patronic physics and their QCD interpretations. The course will close with a summary of questions of current research interest.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic Quantum Chromodynamics methods
Knowledge of partonic interpretations of specific processes
